verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, 'Let me choose twelve thousand men, and tonight I will pursue David.'
verses.comment: Ahithophel’s advice is immediate and strategic, showing his prowess as a counselor. This sets up the tension between human wisdom and divine providence, a recurring theme also suggested in Proverbs 16:9.

verses.text: 'I will attack him while he is weary and discouraged, and I will throw him into a panic. All the people with him will flee, and I will strike down only the king.'
verses.comment: Ahithophel aims for a decisive and targeted strike. The notion of sparing the people and focusing on the leader subtly mirrors later teachings on obedience and authority (cf. Rom. 13:1-2).

verses.text: 'Then I will bring back all the people to you, as the return of all depends on the man whom you seek. All the people will be at peace.'
verses.comment: Ahithophel’s plan seeks to restore unity through singular action. The notion of unity echoes concepts of a restored people gathered around a leader, reminiscent of spiritual unity under a faithful shepherd (cf. Ezek. 34:23).

verses.text: Absalom and all the elders of Israel agreed; Ahithophel’s advice seemed right to them all.
verses.comment: Consensus among the elders highlights how group decisions are sometimes swayed by cunning advice rather than seeking the Lord's will (cf. Prov. 3:5-6).

verses.text: But Absalom said, 'Call Hushai the Archite, and let us hear what he has to say also.'
verses.comment: Absalom doubles back for more counsel, allowing God’s hidden plan to unfold—a reminder that earthly wisdom alone is not sufficient (see Gen. 41:38).

verses.text: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him, 'Ahithophel has said this. Should we follow his advice? If not, speak.'
verses.comment: Hushai is given a chance to offer alternative counsel. The narrative hints at the providence of God working through faithful servants, as seen with Joseph and Daniel (cf. Dan. 2:14).

verses.text: Hushai replied to Absalom, 'This time, Ahithophel’s advice is not good.'
verses.comment: Hushai contests the wise counselor, exemplifying prudence and discernment, virtues praised in wisdom literature (cf. Prov. 1:5).

verses.text: 'You know your father and his men; they are mighty warriors, and now they are enraged, like a mother bear robbed of her cubs in the field. Your father is experienced in war and will not spend the night with the troops.'
verses.comment: Vivid imagery underscores David’s military prowess. The protection described here ties into God’s care for His chosen leaders (cf. Ps. 18:2).
